items.title: Australia's largest literary festival scrapped after speakers quit over ouster of Palestinian writer
items.summary_auto: Organizers of Australia's largest free literary festival cancelled the event Tuesday after more than 180 writers and speakers withdrew over the scrapping of an appearance by an Australian-Palestinian writer and academic.

items.title: Arson suspect in attack on historic Mississippi synagogue admitted to antisemitic motive, FBI alleges
items.summary_auto: A suspect in an arson fire at a synagogue that was bombed by the Ku Klux Klan decades ago admitted to targeting the historic institution because it's a Jewish house of worship and confessed what he had done to his father, who turned him in to authorities after observing burn marks on his son's ankles, hands and face, the FBI said Monday.

items.title: Millions of temporary residents will have to leave Canada when their permits expire. But will they?
A stranger jumped in to give CPR to save this Ontario man, allowing his family one last goodbye
items.summary_auto: A family from Kitchener, Ont., wants to find and say thank you to a Good Samaritan who gave their loved one CPR, extending his life until paramedics arrived on the scene, transported him to hospital and gave his family a chance to say one last goodbye.

items.title: 2.1M temporary residents will have expired or expiring permits this year. But will they leave Canada?
items.summary_auto: Ottawa says 2.1 million temporary residents will have expired or expiring permits this year. But experts say some will consider going underground and undocumented.

items.title: Who was Trevor Dubois? Loved ones want people to understand the man they knew
items.summary_auto: Trevor Dubois is being remembered by friends and family as a man defined by laughter, compassion and advocacy. Those closest to him describe an outgoing, flamboyant and deeply kind man who was known for helping Indigenous youth and others struggling with mental health in Saskatchewan.

items.title: Kitchener, Ont., woman looking for stranger who helped family say one last goodbye to her stepdad
items.summary_auto: A family from Kitchener, Ont., wants to find and say thank you to a Good Samaritan who gave their loved one CPR, extending his life until paramedics arrived on the scene, transported him to hospital and gave his family a chance to say one last goodbye.

items.title: Hundreds still waiting to be airlifted out of Kashechewan First Nation amid water emergency, gastrointestinal outbreak
items.summary_auto: More than 700 people have been evacuated from Kashechewan First Nation following the failure of the community’s water treatment plant.

items.title: ‘It’s heartbreaking’: Royal Canadian Legion closes 99-year-old Halifax branch
items.summary_auto: The Vimy legion branch was closed on Friday night after a meeting with officials from Nova Scotia/Nunavut Command, which is responsible for all branches in the province.

items.title: People inside Iran describe heavy security and scattered damage in 1st calls to outside world
items.summary_auto: Iranians could call abroad on mobile phones Tuesday for the first time since communications were halted during a crackdown on nationwide protests in which activists said at least 646 people have been killed.

items.title: ‘Frequent flyers’ behind surge in violence on public transit
We started drinking more during the pandemic — and that habit hasn't changed much, a new survey finds
items.summary_auto: Many people are starting 2026 by taking part in Dry January, swearing off alcohol for the first month of the year. But new research from the Centre for Addiction and Mental Health (CAMH) is raising concerns about how much Canadians are drinking.

items.title: Durham, Ont., police officers with PTSD say the service fights against their workplace benefits
Overcrowding at Niagara jail reaches 6-year peak, with 40% more inmates since 2019
items.summary_auto: The Niagara correction workers union president says employees struggle to provide programming as jail population increases and the mother of son who died at the detention centre said he had been sleeping on mattresses of his cell's floor.

items.title: B.C. trial to test whether RCMP violated press freedoms in arresting journalist
items.summary_auto: A five-week trial is beginning in a lawsuit launched by photojournalist Amber Bracken, arrested by RCMP in 2021, and news outlet The Narwhal, claiming wrongful arrest, wrongful detention and violation of Charter rights.

items.title: No Name beef burgers recalled due to risk of E. coli
items.summary_auto: No Name brand frozen beef burgers that were sold across the country are being recalled due to a risk of E. coli contamination.

items.title: B.C. Court of Appeal sides with Purolator after COVID-19 vaccine mandate led to hundreds of firings
items.summary_auto: The B.C. Court of Appeal has set aside the decision of a labour administrator who found in favour of Purolator employees who were fired for not getting the COVID-19 vaccine.

items.title: Toronto Maple Leafs player pays tribute to late grocery store worker who loved team
items.summary_auto: A Toronto Maple Leafs player paid tribute over the weekend to a grocery store worker and fan who died suddenly last week and who is being remembered as a warm, friendly face who loved the team.

items.title: U.S. tells its citizens to leave Iran, as Trump pressures Tehran over protest crackdown
items.summary_auto: The United States is telling its citizens to leave Iran, as Washington maintains its pressure on Tehran to cease its crackdown on protesters and U.S. President Donald Trump threatens to strike the Iranian government over the issue

items.title: Minnesota sues Trump administration over immigration operations | Hanomansing Tonight
items.summary_auto: Officials in Minnesota are suing the federal government over what they call a 'dangerous' immigration enforcement, looking to stop the deployment of thousands of immigration agents to the state.

items.title: Why criminal investigation into U.S. Federal Reserve chair crosses red line for key Republicans
Why criminal investigation into Fed chair crosses red line for key Republicans
items.summary_auto: Even for some Republicans who’ve been staunch supporters of U.S. President Donald Trump, the move by the Department of Justice to launch a criminal investigation into the Federal Reserve and its chair Jerome Powell is a red line that should not be crossed.

items.title: Why autism advocates are celebrating Barbie's first-ever autistic doll
items.summary_auto: In an attempt to help 'more children to see themselves represented in Barbie,' toy creator Mattel Inc. is releasing their first-ever autistic Barbie doll.

items.title: Pro-Nazi social media posts lead to courtroom argument between Calgary teen, judge
items.summary_auto: A 19-year-old Calgary man who was once placed on a terrorism peace bond for social media posts promoting ISIS and the killing of gay men got into an argument with a judge about his pro-Nazi beliefs.

items.title: Mother of woman allegedly pushed from 3rd-storey balcony speaks out
items.summary_auto: Tadjan’ah Desir, 31, died in hospital four days after she was allegedly pushed from the balcony of a building in Montreal’s Mercier–Hochelaga-Maisonneuve borough. Laval resident James Theramene is facing a charge of aggravated assault in connection with her death.

items.title: Military members arrive in Pimicikimak Cree Nation amid water woes
items.summary_auto: The chief of a Manitoba First Nation in the throes of severe water issues, including flooding and backed-up sewage, says seven members of the Canadian Armed Forces have arrived to help.

items.title: Family of woman forced to transfer for medical assistance in dying takes case to court
items.summary_auto: Proceedings got underway in B.C. Supreme Court Monday in a case that will determine whether faith-based health care organizations can continue to prohibit medical assistance in dying (MAID) within their facilities.

items.title: Co-accused in couple's Ontario murder trial testifies she wasn't prepared to deal with boy's high needs
items.summary_auto: Becky Hamber has testified for the first time at the weeks-long murder trial that has already seen co-accused Brandy Cooney take the witness box. Hamber told Milton, Ont., court Monday that she struggled to care for the 12-year-old boy who died and his brother who were in their care, but she wanted the best for them.

items.title: Judge sends Saskatoon bus driver to jail for driving drunk with 52 kids on board
items.summary_auto: A Saskatoon judge says a bus driver who mixed alcohol and pain killers while driving a charter bus with 52 children aboard posed an "outrageous" risk.

items.title: Greenpeace calls for more transparency from Canada's largest pulp and paper company
items.summary_auto: Environmental group Greenpeace is calling for more transparency from Domtar, saying it has received millions of dollars in government funding without providing the public with details of how that money is being used or sharing its plans for the future of Canada's forests.

items.title: They're strapped for supplies, and danger looms. But Gaza’s children are thrilled to be back in school
items.summary_auto: Children in the Gaza Strip are resuming their education after two years of near-constant Israeli bombardment.

items.title: What's happening in Iran? Breaking down the deadly protests shaking the country
items.summary_auto: Nationwide protests have been shaking Iran for weeks. They started Dec. 28 in response to soaring prices, then turned into wider anti-government protests against the clerical rulers who have governed the country for nearly 50 years.

items.title: Yukon earthquake reveals a fault line hidden beneath glaciers
items.summary_auto: An earthquake which struck near the Alaska-Yukon border last month has revealed a fault line hidden beneath ice, drawing international research interest.

items.title: Air Canada worker trapped in baggage hold of Toronto-to-Moncton plane freed before takeoff
items.summary_auto: An Air Canada Rouge flight 1502 was taxiing toward the runway last month at Toronto Pearson Airport when passengers heard banging and cries for help from below.

items.title: Average asking rents fell to just over $2K in December — their lowest in more than 2 years
items.summary_auto: Asking rents in Canada fell 2.3 per cent year-over-year in December to an average of $2,060, marking a full calendar year of declines as prices reached their lowest level in 30 months.

items.title: U.S. Sen. Mark Kelly sues the Pentagon over his censure, calling it 'unconstitutional'
items.summary_auto: Democratic Sen. Mark Kelly sued the Pentagon on Monday over attempts to punish him over his participation in a video that called on U.S. troops to resist unlawful orders.

items.title: Heated Rivalry author Rachel Reid to publish a new book in the Game Changers series this September
items.summary_auto: The Nova Scotia-based author of Heated Rivalry has announced Unrivaled, the latest book in her bestselling hockey romance series. The novel will be published on Sept. 26, 2026.

items.title: 2 Native American-owned corporations cancel contracts with ICE
items.summary_auto: Last week, a second Native American-owned corporation announced it was severing a multi-million dollar contract with United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), after community pressure.
